												I like my racing games and I enjoy my puzzle games. Racer 8 is a budget shifting tile puzzle game where you must ensure that your racer makes it safely through a checkpoint and to the finish line. Each course is a mix of different tiles, curved tiles, three way turn tiles and a few crossroads. Think of a train on a track that can only go forward and rather than being the engineer, you're the one that ensures the track is laid out properly. If there's no track ahead, then you crash and need to restart the course again.I'll start off with the good. The game has pleasing, cute, simple almost cartoon in a way graphics. Everything looks sleek and uniform. You can purchase more cars and different paint jobs for them with the points you earn for racing. Each vehicle has its own stats for acceleration, deceleration and whatever 100% scr is. The game's help system could be a lot more informative than telling me what all of the menu icons are. Its all nice stuff that adds to the longevity of a game with at least fifty courses. Its sad that once a course is done, its done. There's no going back.Before you get to challenge those courses, you face a practice map that's like the others. You do this before anything else in the game. Its best to jump in head first and there's nothing difficult at the start. Once you're done with that, you get to go into the main menu.Since Racer 8 has a rally car theme, its a race and that consists of fuel, speed, a checkpoint, a finish and what amounts to jewels to collect on your way. Once you've been on the track for a while, the checkpoint will spawn and you'll need to rotate tiles to get the vehicle through the gate. With that done, after a few more seconds, the finish line will appear. You'll need to mind your fuel though.While I enjoy puzzle games, these tile puzzle games are among my least favorite, but it takes more than a bad genre to make a bad game. Its the glitches here and there. Things as simple as using the menu. I can click on leader boards, settings and stats to see them, but the problem is, there's no way out of them without closing the game. There are interfaces that look like they should slide up or down. They have arrows indicating it, but there is no mouse wheel support, but more surprising than that, clicking the up or down arrows does nothing as well. Trying to purchase a new vehicle for 200 points when I had 200 points told me that I did not have enough to make the purchase.Then there's playing the game, you click a tile to rotate it left, your right click to make it rotate right. That's simple enough, but to make things more challenging, certain tiles go under construction, making them a wildcard, because they can turn into any different tile. I'm fine with that, its part of the challenge to avoid them, but there are other tiles that shift without me telling them to. There's no warning that they will shift, it just happens. Worse than that, there are a few times when the vehicle has been on the road, about to leave the tile to a road that's connected and it just crashes as if it was driving down a highway with no turns, no cars and then slams into an invisible wall.There are no hot keys and to pause the game, you'll need to mouse click it. To control the racer's throttle, you'll need to click and drag it left to go slower or right to go faster. While faster might get you where you're going, it just takes your mouse away from the tiles it needs to be at. Tapping with a finger would be much better, but even then, you risk a tile rotating when you're busy messing with the speed. The further you drive, the faster the racer seems to go.Trees can obscure your vision of the course and tiles. Could you imagine if Tetris blocked out part of your screen? The game's camera is cumbersome. You need to click the camera icon and mess with a slider. The slider raises or lowers the camera and you can click and drag the camera around. It will always continue to look down on the map like its a chess board. Racer 8 is a touch screen for sure. A top down perspective would have been advantageous, but it would have taken away from the style the game has.Everything culminates in a bad game. A budget title with menus that force you to close the game, a less preferred genre in general with a problematic camera. Its difficult to recommend this game to anyone but tile puzzle lovers on touch screen devices. Even then, there are still issues to contend with.

												One of the worst designed games Ive ever seen, thats not an exageration. There are obviously worse games in existence but to fail so spectacularly on every conceivable level at what is essentially Pipe Mania with a twist...Where do I even begin?-It deliberately obfuscates your view so you cant see whats happening with the track. (Im not using a tablet you clowns, optimise your damn game if you want to sell it at four times the price on PC to subsidise your mobile crap.)-There is no aerial view in the camera angles and it resets the angle every game. -The list of your statistics are all wrong. (0 refuels? Not quite right...)-Try to get a better view of the course and it actually starts fogging out parts, which is apparently a feature.-If you run out of fuel as you get to the finish line the game doesnt know what to do with itself.-If you crash a huge crash logo comes up blocking your view. (Given the way it has a tendency to screw you up by changing tiles itd be nice to actually see what cheap crap the game pulled on you this time.)-25 levels in and they are all basically identical. It changes only in how many dumb things are getting in the way of you seeing what the hell is going on, and how long you have to put up with the frustration of playing the game.-Several times I collected every fuel icon that came up promptly and still ran out before the end. -Blue tokens you use to buy the upgrades that make the game at all playable are accrued at an insanely tedious rate while each upgrade can be lost in an instant setting you back dozens of games worth of collecting them each time.-Instant setting back dozens of games? Yeah, because all your upgrades are taken away the moment you crash for any reason including all of the unavoidable broken crashes Ive already mentioned.-In game power up items like fuel are sometimes trapped by the random way in which the board changes so you drive around for the next minute or so hoping for the board to change in a way that will let you collect it while slowly and inevitably leading up to you breaking down.-When I bought auto driver and changed some tiles to build a route to go down it switched the route already laid out causing the car to crash instantly. (It did actually give me a bit of a laugh, but I cant give the game a pass for being literally laughably terrible.)-Even though I had the tokens and some of the shop items are only available in the game, at no point would it let me buy them. Not while playing, not after a crash, not after running out of fuel. Sometimes I could, sometimes I couldnt.This is not an exhaustive list; I could go on (Scoreboard is messed up), and on (About page has broken overlapping text), almost every aspect has a half dozen levels of awful to get through. The entire approach appears to be 'Make the game as frustrating and broken as possible, then have them retry it dozens of times in order to buy "upgrades" that return the game to a semblance of playability.' This game type was perfected almost 30 years ago. This demonstration of how badly you can screw it up is almost impressive.At full price youd have to be profoundly masochistic to purchase this, but in case you see it on sale. I got it for 39pence, and part of why Im writing this review is because I think everyone involved in this game still owes me the satisfaction of ragging on this trash for having the gall to think they could sell it at any price...Im not a fan is basically what Im getting at. Stay well, well away.

												This is a direct port of a game made for mobile phones and tablets. As such, there is no keypad support, no fullscreen; only one mouse button and the option to connect to facebook. I mention the lack of keypad support because as of this moment, after traveling a mere 26 tiles (most of which were in a circle) my car has been stuck between two tiles for the past forty minutes, spinning its wheels endlessly as the map continues to change around it. Without an in-level menu screen my only options are to exit the game entirely by closing the window or to wait until I run out of gas. The latter seems like it's going to take a while, and having already left to make and subsequently eat breakfast, I figured I could write a review while it runs in the background.Racer 8 is a clone of the classic game Pipe Mania (or Pipe Dream in the US), only instead of using sections of pipe to redirect sewage (or "flooz") to a designated point, you click on sections of raceway to direct a small car around a map towards where you think a checkpoint or the finish line might appear; and unlike Pipe Mania's unobstructed view of your handiwork from above, Racer 8 gives you an isometric view of its cluttered, constantly-shifting raceways. And they are cluttered; part of the difficulty of these "puzzles" is that the game doesn't want you to see them, and even without rain, snow, and night driving, you'll have plenty of trees, penants, and banners obstructing your view. Clicking the Move Camera icon pauses the game and lets you get a better view for a few moments, but it won't let you get the best view for this kind of puzzle, that being from above and without so many stupid trees in the way.Even in those levels where you can see the road, any kind of planning or strategy is impossible. The goal of the game is to drive your car through the checkpoint tiles and, eventually, the finish line tile, but those tiles don't actually spawn at the start of the map; they show up at some prespecified time in a part of the map you have no way of knowing you should be heading towards, which makes the directions to "head to the finish" a bit of a cruel joke on the part of the developers. After that you have Men at Work signs, which section off one specific tile and change it into a random tile type. This isn't a problem when it chooses a tile a ways away from you or behind you, but it can instead choose to turn the tile directly in front of yours into a straightway facing the wrong direction and cause you to crash instantly. It might also turn it into a two- or three-way fork, which give no clear visual indication of which way the leadfooted elderly person driving your car is going to turn. Knowing which way Ardy Leadfoot is going to turn outside of the tutorial requires either some degree of prescience, or the unexplained Co-Driver upgrade, which at least gives you two tiles of warning.It was after buying the Co-Driver upgrade that I realised I had enough for the Auto-Driver upgrade. You would think you already had one, what with the car being beyond your control, but what it really does is rearrange the tiles in front of you so you don't crash, doing so at speeds beyond human ability. Yes, essentially you can upgrade the game to play itself, which I take as a sign that even the developers knew nobody would want to play this buggy piece of garbage.Pick it up for free if you can, farm it for the cards, then never touch it again.

												Racer 8's interface was designed with mobile devices in mind, and it shows it.  You scroll through over-sized menu items by dragging the box up and down, ignoring the arrows which appear only to indicate you can.  The game starts windowed, and while a standard Alt+Enter grants you a less messy-looking fullscreen option, this only makes it harder to find the close window option, which you will want shortly after your first level.The game itself gives you a puzzle, ala Pipe Mania (circa 1989), except where your little car needs to travel is not clear from the start.  In fact, you have to mess around waiting for objectives to appear, so planning in advance is an option available only to better games than this.  As far as I can tell, there are no differences in the levels (I admit to not having played that many, wishing to retain a semblance of sanity in order to write this review) although it was raining on one level which I'm sure was nice.A special shout-out has to go to the Auto-Pilot "upgrade", which makes assumptions about you wanting to hit walls and fail, so changes routes for you accordingly.As a special treat, you can connect this game to your Facebook account.  The developers are clearly in touch with the demands of modern gaming, and should of course be applauded.Full disclosure: I got this game for free, though still feel a little over-charged.

												This is not a racing game. This is a puzzle game.The car follows the track, and you can click to rotate each of the track pieces. Randomly, one piece will mutate into another one. And that's the entire gameplay.Why am I giving a negative review? Because...* The camera angle is terrible.* It would have been better if this game was a 2D game instead. Instead, by making it a 3D game with a fixed camera angle, the game gets artificially more difficult and more confusing. (actually, you can slightly change the camera height by clicking on a button at the left side of the screen, but the angle is still terrible)* The extraneous graphic elements, such as trees and even clouds, serve no purpose other than trying to look good and instead obscuring your view.* There is no animation for the track rotation. It just instantly rotates 90 degrees.* You can only click with the left mouse button. So, you can only rotate tracks in one direction.* There are no options. It runs in a window with a fixed size.* It has built-in coins to implement some kind of progression grinding. For what? For more cars! And for paint jobs!* It has some kind of Facebook integration, but it does not work.* The music gets annoying pretty fast.* It looks like a mobile game that was quickly ported to PC without much thought. Heck, even as a mobile game it is not good.* The game progress is saved at the Windows Registry.* It is boring.The PC Gaming Wiki lists some command-line options to change the resolution.I like the core gameplay concept, but I dislike this implementation. Avoid this game.

YouTube™ Video: Spongebob Driving Exam Allahu Akbar 

			Views: 51,818		

			Allahu Akbar		

(This game in a nutshell)Wow...that didn't last long....PLEASE tell me this was a school project....By the title, you'll assume, "Huh...this will be a boring racing game".   By that, you're half right, but also half wrong.  It's a boring puzzle game.  Didn't finish all 50 levels, but then again, why would I?   No achievements and all levels are pretty much the same thing.  (Stopped at level 11)You're essentially playing pipe dream, only with a single car, tiles that randomly change on you, and a fuel meter that acts as your time counter.  Expect to crash often and don't expect victory to be satisfying.Pros:Graphics look decent.May tickle the fancy of those who are puzzle fetishists.Card drops to sell.Not bugged.Cons:Monotonous.  (Same thing every stage.  Why have levels at all?)You're going to use a slow speed for most of the game, even though you can increase the speed at any given time.You click an option and the only way out is to reclick that same button (You'd think that pressing escape would be enough to back out...)Calling this game a "Racer" is false advertisement.Only real difficulty (That is...the change as you progress) is the gas limit (or time limit) and blindspots.No achievements (meaning no incentive for me to continue)As a project developed by 3 guys and tested by 6 people, there is not much here to be "stellar" about.  At least the game isn't bugged, so I can't fault the devs there.  But the imagination here is lacking.Personally, I don't really like it.    I only found it to be worth 18 minutes of gameplay (as of typing this review)....now to wait for the card drops....  But at least I got the game for free, so selling the cards will at least provide a profit.


Pretty much all this game is.  Don't expect to win... And when you do win, don't expect victory to be satisfying.

												Unpolished, broken, boredomContrary to the name, Racer 8 is a puzzle game (not a racing one). Gameplay is a mess. You start off with a car which you have to guide through checkpoints and then the finish line. Each level places you in a different course to play. After, going through the finish line the game will end, you will earn credits and be able to proceed to the next level. Credits are used in the store to buy new vehicles or change vehicle colour. The roads can be manipulated to change the direction the car is going. The car moves automatically and can't be controlled by the player. If the car reaches an unconnected road, it will crash and you will be forced to restart the level. You can choose to increase the rate the car is moving, although there is no point. The problem is that you have to manipulate the roads WHILE the car is still moving, with no option to stop it, so increasing the car's speed will hinder your efforts to manipulate the roads quick enough. Another problem is that the checkpoints and finish lines don't appear right away, so you are forced to 'juggle' the car before they appear. Another issue is that it is difficult to determine which direction the car will go at intersections as there is limited indication on the roads, therefore making it difficult to arrange. There are also a few menu issues as well as some menus require you to press on a different 'menu icon' to exit the current menu, while others require you to press the 'same menu' to exit. I wish there war an option to pause the game and view the map at the same time. Such an option would help the player to plan their road adjustments without the unnecessary pressure.Audio is forgettable. Music is isn't remarkable as the same title song is repeated in main menu. Gameplay music is quiet, but nothing special. There is no voice acting in the game.Graphics aren't that great. Terrain and vehicles lack texture detail. Models are simple as well.If you are looking for a good puzzle game, stay clear of 'Racer 8'.

												Racer 8 is a casual, racing puzzler where you rotate the race track, which is divided into tiles, to reach the end of the race. There are a few constraints presented that make this task more difficult, like a fuel meter, changing weather patterns & tiles that change on their own, albeit with prior notice. There are power-ups that you can obtain that will benefit you along the race, like mitigating your rate of speed & granting more fuel. There is also a shop where you can purchase useful boosts at the beginning of each race, with the coins granted from winning races.Racer 8 does nothing particularly well. The graphics, gameplay & sound are all very generic. There isn’t anything to hold your interest longer than a couple minutes at a time.The only thing going for Racer 8 is that it is unique in the Puzzler genre, at least on the Steam platform. There isn’t anything remotely similar to it.
